articles.headline: Two Bombings Wreak Carnage in Iraqi Capital
articles.snippet: Two women strapped with explosives killed dozens of people in the deadliest day in Baghdad in months.
articles.abstract: Two women strapped with explosives killed dozens of people in the deadliest day in Baghdad in months.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Two women strapped with explosives killed dozens of people at Baghdad pet markets on Friday, in the kind of carnage that the Iraqi capital hoped it had left behind.
articles.byline: By STEPHEN FARRELL and MUDHAFER AL-HUSAINI

articles.headline: Yahoo Offer Is Strategy Shift for Microsoft
articles.snippet: Google’s dominance has forced Microsoft to concede that it did not get its Internet business right.
articles.abstract: Google’s dominance has forced Microsoft to concede that it did not get its Internet business right.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft and a global philanthropist, called upon fellow business leaders at the World Economic Forum last week to pursue a kinder form of capitalism.

articles.headline: Wesley Snipes Cleared of Serious Tax Charges
articles.snippet: The actor was convicted on three lesser charges and must pay up to $17 million of back taxes, penalties and interest.
articles.abstract: The actor was convicted on three lesser charges and must pay up to $17 million of back taxes, penalties and interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: OCALA, Fla.  A federal jury returned a mixed verdict against the actor Wesley Snipes on Friday, acquitting him of the most serious tax charges he faced, but convicting him on three of six lesser charges. The case was the most prominent tax prosecution since the billionaire hotelier Leona Helmsley was convicted of tax fraud in 1989.

articles.headline: A Giant Bid That Shows How Tired the Giant Is
articles.snippet: The proposed Yahoo deal is a confirmation that Microsoft has become exactly what Bill Gates used to fear — sluggish and bureaucratic.
articles.abstract: The proposed Yahoo deal is a confirmation that Microsoft has become exactly what Bill Gates used to fear — sluggish and bureaucratic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oh, how the mighty have fallen.

articles.headline: Alcoa and Chinese Rival Buy 12% Stake in Rio Tinto
articles.snippet: The move underscored the strategic significance of mining in a resource-stretched age as well as China’s formidable and still largely untapped economic might.
articles.abstract: The move underscored the strategic significance of mining in a resource-stretched age as well as China’s formidable and still largely untapped economic might.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  The state-owned giant Aluminum Corporation of China and the Aluminum Corporation of America stunned analysts and investors Friday by buying a minority stake in Rio Tinto, the world’s third largest mining company.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Massachusetts Accuses Merrill of Fraud
articles.snippet: The state’s top securities regulator accused Merrill Lynch on Friday of defrauding the city of Springfield with subprime-linked investments.
articles.abstract: The state’s top securities regulator accused Merrill Lynch on Friday of defrauding the city of Springfield with subprime-linked investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts accused Merrill Lynch on Friday of defrauding the city of Springfield with subprime-linked investments, casting light on how Wall Street banks sold complex mortgage securities that are now plummeting in value as the housing slump deepens.

articles.headline: First Job Losses in 4 Years Raise Recession Fears
articles.snippet: Employers cut 17,000 jobs in January, the first decline in the work force in more than four years.
articles.abstract: Employers cut 17,000 jobs in January, the first decline in the work force in more than four years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s employers eliminated 17,000 jobs in January, the government reported Friday, the first decline in the work force in more than four years, and the strongest signal yet that the United States may be in the early stages of a recession.
articles.byline: By Louis Uchitelle and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Clinton’s Gradual Education on Issues of Race
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who grew up in the palest of Chicago suburbs,  is now competing for black votes across the South.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who grew up in the palest of Chicago suburbs,  is now competing for black votes across the South.

articles.headline: Eyes on Google, Microsoft Bids $44 Billion for Yahoo
articles.snippet: If consummated, the deal would instantly redraw the competitive landscape on the Internet and escalate the battle between Microsoft and Google.
articles.abstract: If consummated, the deal would instantly redraw the competitive landscape on the Internet and escalate the battle between Microsoft and Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, was finishing a regularly scheduled company board meeting Thursday night when his assistant interrupted him with an urgent phone call.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Kennedy Revels in Limelight as He Stumps for Obama
articles.snippet: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the white-haired liberal legend, is drawing raucous crowds.
articles.abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the white-haired liberal legend, is drawing raucous crowds.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M.  “Are you glad to see me, Santa Fe?” Edward M. Kennedy roared.

articles.headline: Democrats Flood States With Ads as Tuesday Nears
articles.snippet: A concentrated burst of advertising is highlighting the diverging financial fortunes of the two parties.
articles.abstract: A concentrated burst of advertising is highlighting the diverging financial fortunes of the two parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have unleashed advertisements in nearly all the 22 states that have Democratic presidential nominating contests on Tuesday, a combined $19 million expenditure that is the most ambitious and geographically expansive television effort in a presidential primary.

articles.headline: Lenders Who Sold and Left
articles.snippet: The mortgage brokers, traders and bankers who took in big bucks steering customers into subprime loans should not be allowed to slink offstage without recognition.
articles.abstract: The mortgage brokers, traders and bankers who took in big bucks steering customers into subprime loans should not be allowed to slink offstage without recognition.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE Federal Bureau of Investigation said last week that it had opened criminal investigations into 14 companies that played a part in the mortgage boom and bust. While it did not identify the companies on its dance card, the F.B.I. said they included mortgage brokers, lenders, and the Wall Street banks that packaged and sold the securities. Investigators are looking for accounting fraud and possible insider trading at the companies, an F.B.I. spokesman said.

articles.headline: Yahoo Sale Could Be Bad for Minnows
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s proposed mega-bid for Yahoo is based on its own particular corporate needs and may not be a harbinger of rampant deal-making in Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s proposed mega-bid for Yahoo is based on its own particular corporate needs and may not be a harbinger of rampant deal-making in Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  FOR decades, Silicon Valley has been the land of eternal optimism and high anxiety, traits that pitch into overdrive anytime a seismic business event washes across the corporate and entrepreneurial landscape here  like, for example, Microsoft’s blockbuster $45 billion bid for Yahoo on Friday.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: A Frail Economy Raises Pressure on Iran’s Rulers
articles.snippet: From fundamentalists to reformists, Iranians are talking more loudly about the need for a pragmatic approach.
articles.abstract: From fundamentalists to reformists, Iranians are talking more loudly about the need for a pragmatic approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  In one of the coldest winters Iranians have experienced in recent memory, the government is failing to provide natural gas to tens of thousands of people across the country, leaving some for days or even weeks with no heat at all. Here in the capital, rolling blackouts every night for a month have left people without electricity, and heat, for hours at a time.

articles.headline: Nuclear Leaks and Response Tested Obama in Senate
articles.snippet: An Illinois controversy pitting two important constituencies against each other put Barack Obama’s legislative skills to the test.
articles.abstract: An Illinois controversy pitting two important constituencies against each other put Barack Obama’s legislative skills to the test.
articles.lead_paragraph: When residents in Illinois voiced outrage two years ago upon learning that the Exelon Corporation had not disclosed radioactive leaks at one of its nuclear plants, the state’s freshman senator, Barack Obama, took up their cause.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Chief Can’t Stop Looking Over His Shoulder
articles.snippet: A feud over influence at American International Group, the world’s largest insurer, continues in legal papers and in public.
articles.abstract: A feud over influence at American International Group, the world’s largest insurer, continues in legal papers and in public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Martin J. Sullivan, now 53, took over the world’s largest insurer, the American International Group, three years ago, the company was the target of multiple criminal and civil investigations and its books were in such disarray that its auditors refused to endorse them. During Mr. Sullivan’s first 18 months on the job, A.I.G.’s bottom line was successively pounded by three huge hurricanes and a South Asian earthquake. Then came an equally costly disaster, though one of human origin: the subprime credit market meltdown.

articles.headline: Yahoo Deal Is Big, but Is It the Next Big Thing?
articles.snippet: In Silicon Valley, buying rather than building from the bottom up is seen as counter to the reinvention culture.
articles.abstract: In Silicon Valley, buying rather than building from the bottom up is seen as counter to the reinvention culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In moving to buy Yahoo, Microsoft may be firing the final shot of yesterday’s war.

articles.headline: Even as the Candidates Make Nice, the TV Crew Hopes for a Fight
articles.snippet: A serious discussion on pressing national issues may be good for the country. But it isn’t necessarily good television.
articles.abstract: A serious discussion on pressing national issues may be good for the country. But it isn’t necessarily good television.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  A serious discussion on pressing national issues may be good for the country. But it isn’t necessarily good television.

articles.headline: It’s Splitsville for Rupert and Hillary
articles.snippet: With its endorsement of Barack Obama, Rupert Murdoch and The New York Post tack in a different direction.
articles.abstract: With its endorsement of Barack Obama, Rupert Murdoch and The New York Post tack in a different direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Honeymoons don’t last forever. Just ask Hillary Clinton and Rupert Murdoch.

articles.headline: A Battle of the Moguls Over IAC
articles.snippet: A battle royal shaping up between Barry Diller and John C. Malone over IAC/Interactive is not about their personal differences, despite the juicy material this provides.
articles.abstract: A battle royal shaping up between Barry Diller and John C. Malone over IAC/Interactive is not about their personal differences, despite the juicy material this provides.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like Hollywood stars stuck in a rut, Barry Diller and John C. Malone are always cast in the same contrasting roles. Mr. Diller, 65, lives a razzle-dazzle life of extravagance and celebrity. If he isn’t flying off to Capri with his wife, the socialite and fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg, he is running his company, IAC/InterActiveCorp, from a sculptured $133 million tower designed by Frank Gehry on the Hudson River.
articles.byline: By Geraldine Fabrikant and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Google Works to Torpedo Microsoft Bid for Yahoo
articles.snippet: Google is making an unusually aggressive effort to block Microsoft’s $44.6 billion hostile bid for Yahoo.
articles.abstract: Google is making an unusually aggressive effort to block Microsoft’s $44.6 billion hostile bid for Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing between a marriage of Microsoft and Yahoo may be the technology behemoth that has continually outsmarted them: Google.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: McCain Looks Confident; Tighter Democratic Race
articles.snippet: John McCain was striving to end the Republican race on Tuesday, while polls showed Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lead over Barack Obama was narrowing.
articles.abstract: John McCain was striving to end the Republican race on Tuesday, while polls showed Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lead over Barack Obama was narrowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain, buoyed by new polls and endorsements, appeared in an increasingly commanding position on Sunday as he headed toward coast-to-coast contests that could effectively hand him the Republican presidential nomination, party officials said. In a display of confidence, Mr. McCain campaigned in the backyard of his chief rival, Mitt Romney.

articles.headline: France Said to Suggest New Controls for Its Banks
articles.snippet: The French government is calling for tighter risk-control measures and a broad review of bank rules in response to losses from the trading scandal at Société Générale.
articles.abstract: The French government is calling for tighter risk-control measures and a broad review of bank rules in response to losses from the trading scandal at Société Générale.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  A French government report to be released Monday calls for tighter risk-control measures at Société Générale and a broad review of the rules at other French banks in response to huge losses from a trading scandal, French officials with direct knowledge of the findings said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and James Kanter

articles.headline: Great Firewall of China Faces Online Rebels
articles.snippet: The Chinese government’s censorship of Web sites with no discernible political content has fostered a backlash.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government’s censorship of Web sites with no discernible political content has fostered a backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China  As an 18-year-old student with an interest in the Internet, Zhu Nan had been itching to say something about the country’s pervasive online censorship system, widely known here as the Great Firewall.

articles.headline: In Democratic Families, Politics Makes for Estranged Bedfellows
articles.snippet: Political dynasties and ordinary people alike have found their houses divided between support for Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Political dynasties and ordinary people alike have found their houses divided between support for Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maria Shriver woke up Sunday morning and decided to surprise the audience at a rally for Senator Barack Obama in Los Angeles, materializing alongside Oprah Winfrey and telling the crowd she was there because she sought “an America that’s about unity.”

articles.headline: Another Difficulty for a Microsoft-Yahoo Marriage: Recruiting
articles.snippet: In an industry that favors start-ups, a faint stodginess clings to Microsoft and Yahoo that could impede their  ability to draw top engineering talent.
articles.abstract: In an industry that favors start-ups, a faint stodginess clings to Microsoft and Yahoo that could impede their  ability to draw top engineering talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The crowds of engineering students stood as many as six deep at the recruitment table Google set up at a job fair at Stanford last fall. Facebook’s representatives faced a similarly thick crowd clamoring for a few minutes of their time.
articles.byline: By Gary Rivlin and Katie Hafner
